keyTakeAways: Bear attacks in Japan have increased significantly, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported this year — the highest since 2006.
Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the woods near Myoko, Japan.
Halloran sustained serious injuries, including a bitten-off chunk of bone in his arm and claw punctures on his leg, requiring three surgeries including a hip graft and metal plates.
The rise in bear attacks is linked to climate change, which is disrupting natural food sources and causing bears to venture into urban and rural areas in search of food.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the surge in attacks.
Local residents use deterrents like bells, loud music, and bear spray to protect themselves.
Halloran expresses trauma from the attack and acknowledges the risk, but remains determined to return to running and nature, supported by the local running community.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears while running in the woods near Myoko, Japan. The incident occurred amid a surge in bear attacks across Japan — over 100 injuries and seven deaths this year — attributed to climate change disrupting bears' natural food sources. Halloran sustained severe injuries, including a bitten-off bone in his arm and claw wounds on his leg, requiring multiple surgeries and a long recovery. The Japanese government has responded by announcing stricter measures to control bear populations. Residents are advised to use deterrents like bells, loud music, or bear spray. Halloran, though traumatized, remains committed to returning to running and nature, citing the support of the local running community and the need to remain cautious in the face of rising human-bear conflicts.
title: Runner wrestles bear in the Japanese woods: ‘In one bite my arm was done’
